job_title: Family and Community Partnership Monitor in Pasadena, CA
pros: Great benefits, great people, purposeful mission.
cons: Position is not paid enough for having a degree and experience.

job_title: Therapist in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Medical, dental insurance. Paid time off. Working with families that really need support. Supportive coworkers.
cons:
Guaranteed burnout for very low pay. 

Nearly impossible to meet billing requirements and you are not allotted enough time to complete paperwork. You will work unpaid overtime just to get paperwork done. 

Feels like a sad joke to work for a mental health agency that treats employees so poorly.

Clinicians laid off due to budgeting and weren’t given time to communicate with client families, yet management upset when clients did not want to start working with a stranger with no heads up?

Supervision is hit or miss. We had a really difficult supervisor who played favorites and was outwardly hostile. HR disclosed our concerns to the supervisor but did not offer solutions to improve the situation or change in supervisors. This led to more hostility. 

It’s a shame because the families we work with really need and deserve quality clinicians, but working at this agency will burn you out. Even if I had had an amazing supervisor, the pay is very low for the amount of work and makes it hard not to feel taken advantage of. We are not in this work for the money but we still need to survive.

job_title: Mental Health Therapist in Campinas, São Paulo
pros: Great benefits, PTO, nice office, cool coworkers!
cons:
High intensity cases are not spread evenly throughout all of the therapists, so you might end up with a lot of high intensity cases. There is so much paperwork!! Especially with FSP cases, you’ll have a crazy amount of paperwork. The intake schedules are super weird so you end up doing reassessments and intakes for clients that you won’t end up keeping, 
It all seems very unorganized. 
Depending on your supervisor you might end up spending more time on paperwork to fix minor things so takes even more time to get paperwork done on top of seeing all of your clients. Therapists are also being pushed to see kids in schools and in the field with Covid rates rising (and other Pacific Clinics sites are not pushing employees to do this). Overall an ok place to work but if you don’t want to be overly stressed out just pick a different Pacific clinics site.

It’s depressing to attend company meetings and hearing about all the great programs and services they provide knowing that none of them are available for your clients. Staff in the outlieing areas don’t have the same tools or training. Low pay, raises based on minimum wage requirements and cola raises are few and far between.

job_title: Management in Campinas, São Paulo

cons: Greedy management - very liberal and hypocritical. - They make backroom deals with their Blue Shield Broker because they contribute heavily to the organization. They do this to increase employees subscribing to blues shield who then provides lower premiums because more people subscribe - this then increases premiums to other programs (e.g. Kaiser) for employees who do not choose blue shield - it is a very quid pro quo type of institution

review_title: Stepping Stone Job- You can find better. Do not settle for here.
job_title: MHW in Pasadena, CA
pros: On the rare occasion when you get good co workers and management. They are the backbone for this work. Making your own schedule.
cons: Awful, terrible, disrespectful, unprofessional and gaslighting management. I have never felt so bullied in my life by a bunch of people who don't care about about the clients nor staff. If you had a really intense client emergency, all they would ask is "did you bill for it?" completely dismissing or offering debriefing. I feel like I could have been shot in the arm and went to report it to my boss and they would also just ignore it and ask which code I will be billing my shooting under. You're just another dollar sign to them and a small one too unless you're an alien and can reach they outrageous and truly unrealistic billing expectations. I am fully aware that this is a paper pushing job, but bottom line is that we work IN mental health, yet they sadly are blind to respecting ours. How can we help others if we are beaten down on a daily basis?

cons: Bad management; poor structure, direction, working after work hours; rules that make no sense such as decrease of latency of notes after covid, more paperwork after covid, more productivity demands after covid (when telehealth sessions tend to be shorter); not having empathy when clinicians have unexpected emergencies such as wifi outage/getting sick unexpectedly and blaming them for the emergencies and telling them to take less sick days when supervisors are taking more sick days, calling people out when they leave, and going along with abuse from top down.

job_title: Success Coach in Orange, CA
pros:
- Coworkers where amazing and developed very strong relationships with them
-Willing to hire fresh out of college grads with no experience 
-Learned a ton about the different social service resources in the local area
-Can be a great launching pad to build experience and go elsewhere if you want to pursue a career in social/human services or education.
cons:
-Your experience will largely depend on what site you work for, I was at the Recovery Education Institute in Orange, CA and it was very frustrating at best and down right depressing at worst.

-It's important to know that this is a quota based position. That was not made clear to me upon interviewing and may have deterred me had I know. You must meet a monthly number of clientele which you will be responsible for recruiting or bringing in to the office for assistance. If you do not meet this quota you will receive disciplinary action in multiple forms, but usually by having to meet with management and tell them why you haven't met your numbers and how you will make them up in the following month, in addition to that month's numbers. Because of the natural structure of the program numbers tend to dwindle at certain times of the year but you will be expected to fill your quota regardless. The quota is the most important thing to them. I was denied vacation time for not meeting quotas in consecutive months. 

-Micromanagement is the law of the land. This can be helpful when you are new and need a lot of guidance, however it quickly becomes unhelpful once you know how to perform your role. 

- The pay is very low considering all of the roles and responsibilities you will fill and that they are requiring a bachelors degree. As with many jobs, the longer you stay and more seasoned you become the more you get on your plate. However your pay will not increase and there is no position to promote to. 

-Management will not stand behind you when it comes to student confrontation or disrespect. If a student becomes vocally upset or abuses you verbally, it will be entirely up to you and your coworkers to defuse the situation, and if you don't succeed in this you will have to have a meeting with your supervisor to discuss what you could have done better. You will not be provided any training in de-escalation or crisis prevention as you are not considered "clinical" staff. 

-High turn over rate, we had 4 people (not including myself) quit in the two years I worked there, and 2 of them didn't even make a full year. To give you an idea, there are only 9 staff members to begin with, so this can greatly hinder productivity and add new responsibilities to your plate while they search for a new person to fill the role. 

-I could write a book about everything that went on at this place during my time there but overall, if you are fresh out of college, with no experience, and are really struggling to get employment it'll get you by for a year or two until you can move on to something more in line with where you want to be. But if you are someone who is looking to work in mental health or psychology as a career, I'd highly recommend looking elsewhere for something more clinical as the format of this program is geared more toward education than mental health.

review_title: Good place to work for overall

job_title: Lifeguard in Kennewick, WA
pros: The people who work here are fun.
cons: Sometimes there is a break down of communication from some of the managers.

job_title: Therapist in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Own schedule. Free dental and vision. Colleagues.
cons: Low pay. Over worked. Limited advancement in career. Small bump in salary once licensed. Continuous mismanagement of funds.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Pasadena, CA
pros: Great co-workers, numerous trainings available to employees, some room for growth, great "stepping stone" towards your career. The company does have decent benefits and 14 holidays.
cons: Very disorganized! The many divisions of Pacific Clinics seem to have no communication with one another. The organization seems to hold two priorities: expanding and billing. For a non-profit, it is run very similarly to a corporation. I have witnessed the some departments take on new projects without having adequate staff. The employees are extremely over worked and underpaid. The organization has an extremely visible hierarchy which can sometimes feel uncomfortable. Expect to sit in on staff meetings while watching recorded videos of the CEO speaking to the organization. With the changes in health care approaching, the entire organization is in a frenzy. The work never seems to be centered on the client. Billing takes priority over the car of the clients. This is not the fault of the employees, the have to meet at least 5 billable hours per day. Not meeting this could lead to termination or write-ups.

review_title: Working environment depends on your Program Director...
job_title: Milieu Counselor in Monrovia, CA
pros: I really enjoyed the Day Treatment program that I worked at. I thought that the PD at this site was a director. He was very invested in the children as well as in his staff. This was my first job after graduating college and he made it very fun to work here. He took a team approach, so during lunch team meetings you always knew what was going on in other milieus and gave everyone an opportunity to give "staff of the day" to recognize the work that staff did daily. I also really enjoyed the set up for this particular day treatment program, where there was one female staff and one male staff in each milieu. I also had a good supervisor who taught me a lot of interventions with the children. I would say that my positive experience at this place was largely due to having a good team of co workers at this place. I was very fortunate.
cons: I liked working here but i would have to say that the pay is really low. The only way you can advance is if you obtain your masters which is why most of the counselors here will leave to continue their education.

job_title: Mental Health Therapist in Santa Fe Springs, CA
pros: Decent salary for MFT intern/ASW and benefits are good.
cons: If you are looking to build clinical skills do not work at Pacific Clinics.  As most reviews indicate, productivity is of paramount importance and the development of clinicians is last priority.  Clinicians are over worked and spend so much time on DMH paperwork that very little time is spent on the actual treatment.  You are expected to have 30-32 clients and this is not possible given that some client's require a lot of attention.  Any agency that contracts with DMH has this type or similar work load, I've worked for other DMH contracted agencies, however, Pacific Clinics by far is the worst.  I do not believe Pacific Clinics is vested in advancing behavioral healthcare, as their motto states, instead I believe they are more concerned with advancing their bottom line.  I am gravely disappointed in Pacific Clinics and the lack of support & development they provide to clinicians, it is a horrible place to work and this is evidenced by the extremely high turnover.

job_title: Housing in Los Angeles, CA
pros: There is only one individual in the HR department that was actually nice and had some sense.
cons: This company is a joke! They treat the employees like slaves, and they pay slave wages. They also treat the consumers like slaves. The management is horrible they do not have any management skills whatsoever and they all walk around with this power trip. Oh and not to mention all the miss billing they do for their clients. This place sells you a good story when you apply but once you are there it is all a front. There is not sense of leadership nor do they care about their employees. You have to wonder why the employee turn around rate is so high They lack morale, ethics, leadership, organization, respect, and knowledge! You can get away with pretty much anything if you know someone on the inside. They run their staff to the gutter, stress them out and that's why they all leave on stress or quit.

job_title: Supervisor in Glendora, CA
pros: Great benefits and vacation. Loved my colleagues and the team. The work is very meaningful it the politics from executive management weren't there.
cons: High levels of favoritism from executive management. Extremely low pay for line staff while executive management is making between 250k-350k (look up their 990 taxes!). Very unrealistic expectations of productivity and limited in how you are able to provide therapy to clients. There is a lot of extra paperwork outside of the DMH expected paperwork that is pointless and redundant. The company is extremely top heavy.

review_title: Excellent training, concern for clients, high expectations on staff
job_title: Mental Health Therapist in Santa Fe Springs, Los Angeles, CA
pros: Training is provided and encouraged constantly, supervisors are supportive, good medical and fringe benefits, like educational leave, bereavement, vacation and sick time.
cons: As a county contracted agency there is ALWAYS the threat of the county taking away the contract and billables become the priority over clients and especially staff well being. Many positions have high turnover and burn out rates because of this, expectations placed on staff  are unrealistic and lead to disgruntled employees who leave the first chance they get.

review_title: We are stressed to our limits.
job_title: Mental Health Worker II in Pasadena, CA
pros: I love my coworkers and clients. It is rewarding to watch people get their lives back.
cons: The productivity/latency demands are impossible for all but a few people agency wide. The care we give our clients is why we're here. The reason so many leave is due most often to the fact that our performance is judged by numbers. In an intensive program our interventions take an emotional toll ,  documenting within the time constraints required is impossible for most. If you don't keep up you can't get a raise. I have not had a raise of any kind since 2012.

review_title: It depends a lot on the location
job_title: Mental Health Therapist I in Yucca Valley, CA
pros: The benefits are excellent. It's a big corporation, so there are lots of different cities and types of facilities. Some venues have a friendly, family-like atmosphere and are very pleasant to work at.
cons: Not very employee friendly. They claim to put staff first, but it isn't true. They also force you to go to the same city for training at the same time as other new hires, which in my case was a 2.5 hr drive each way and you had to be there early in the morning, stay till rush hour, and do it for several days. Even for explanation of benefits.

job_title: Mental Health Therapist in Los Angeles, CA
pros: 4 weeks vacation...one of the only reasons I'm still here. Line staff that genuinely care about Community mental Health.
cons:
Over about the last two years, there has been EXTREME pressure coming down from management (who, I feel, have NO IDEA what the realities of the work that line staff do) to focus on BILLING and PRODUCTIVITY from staff. This has been to the point where it is increasingly likely to have people fired for not making the cut. While this line of work ahs always been demanding, in previous years though billing and productivity were always stressed as important, I feel as if you were an employee who was trying their best and caring for their clients, you were given a chance to catch up. Nowadays, it's very clear that this part of our job is being micromanaged and that upper management is trying to put rules in place to have consequences for people that are not meeting these requirements. The problem with this is that it is UNREALISTIC to complete our job tasks in the time given. We are not staff who are hanging around all day doing nothing. Client care is important to all of us and we make sure to meet our client's needs. Unfortunately, the way our offices and jobs are setup with many meetings, much administrative paperwork that can't be billed for, non user-friendly computer systems, and too much responsibility being put on line staff for things that are not billable, such as OMA's, the increasing amount of random forms required by either PC or DMH, and understanding of dense MEMO's from random EHIM, HR, or other upper level departments, it is nearly impossible to keep up. 

It is well known that NEARLY ALL therapists and case managers take work home (whilst understanding there is an unspoken rule that they can't really openly express how often this needs to happen) to complete billing. Maybe if PC were more flexible with us to allow us telecommute days or other benefits, we could all be open about how to best get all the work done, but I feel like that use middle level management to shield themselves from the realities of the troubles that line staff face and they just put pressure on management to have us line staff either "figure out a way" to do it on our own, or get fired, or get so stressed out that staff leave.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Great mission; great staff. Employees work hard and the Programs really care about the clients. Excellent vacation and sick time.
cons: Too political. Change can be good but the company has changed for the worst.  The focus is on productivity. Employees work very hard but there is no compassion for them. Very rare 2-4% salary increases & 403b contributions. The employee survey was a joke! Most employees are frustrated.

job_title: Mental Health Worker in Santa Fe Springs, Los Angeles, CA
pros: Great experience applied with diverse population.
cons: The company is simply a "med-cal" billing factory! They overworked you beyond your ability to perform your job efficiently, leafing to high rotation of employees, from case managers to therapist. The company gets frequent state audits which ends of many employees and managers been fired or "removed" due to not producing . You will have to meet your numbers within a couple months of being hired. Benefits are competitive, but they keep changing without respecting your contract. If you interested in this company keep in mind is just for the experience and make an exit plan! The only ones who have a great salary are the Managers and CEO / Board ! stress level is VERY hight! Talk to some of the employees when you get your interview., or you could be a client there pretty soon!!!

job_title: Mental Health Therapist in Santa Fe Springs, Los Angeles, CA
pros:
-Good benefits (vacation time, sick time, maternity leave, etc.)
-Supportive of career (educational stipend of approx $200)
-Supportive supervisors

-High turnover rate because of the above

job_title: Mental Health Therapist in Pasadena, CA
pros: Many free trainings, good colleagues and clients. May be ok for an MFT Intern and if the program director is supportive.
cons: Do not value employees, little support for therapists, great emphasis on quantity over quality, low concern for client care, low pay, mentality that employees are easily replaceable. High turn over, high productivity demands, very difficult to meet expectations within the workday, frequent firings, especially of case managers. Please note, some programs are better than others and satisfaction seems to relate to the program director's ability to support staff and shield them from upper management.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Good holiday and vacation 4 week. Great coworkers.
cons: No raises in over 2 years. Strong turn over rate most people leave after 2 years after they fulfill licensing hour requirements, which causes a lot of stress on recovering clients. Management soft threatens job security in order to extrapolate more billing out of already overworked staff. And most people do work at home for free to keep up with the difficult billing requirement (or you resort to bill unethically). You have 4 weeks of vacation but you feel guilty to take it because you worry about billing.  Morale is low and almost everyone is looking to leave.

review_title: Judgement of Over $1 Million Dollars Against Pacific Clinics
job_title: Director of Human Resources in Arcadia, CA
pros: One  benefit of working for this employer is to obtain work experience to transfer to an ethical, competent employer while watching countless employees resign or be terminated for usually a litany of reasons.
cons:
Pacific Clinics has at least one judgement against them for failing to lawfully pay employees in accordance with California Wage & Hour laws and retaliating against the management level employee of their violations. Judgement records of this nature are public record. 
There are laws governing when and how employers must pay employees.  Pacific Clinics knowingly and willingly continued to withhold wages due to their employees yet continued to conceal bonuses to Executive Management from their employees and lost in arbitration for retaliation against the employee who reported their wage and hour violations.

Despite continuing to obstruct the facts of their violation, they lost more than $1 million dollars to the employee who brought the matter to their attention and alleged that they lawfully and ethically paid their employees.

There is at least a three year statute of limitations for wage and hour violations.  If you are a current or former employee of Pacific Clinics monitor each paycheck to ensure that you were compensated for the hours that you worked and/or provided services and that you receive your meal periods and lunch periods each day.

You may not be retaliated against for protecting your rights and can file a claim with the California Labor Commissioner or speak with a licensed attorney.  You cannot be retaliated against for inquiries of this nature or you may collect more than $1 million dollars, or any amount deemed appropriate by the court.

job_title: in Arcadia, CA
pros: There is a tremendous commitment to the mission of serving those who are less fortunate and very much in need.  The recognition of employees as the greatest asset is paramount.
cons: There are too many managers.  Some places have as many as four people managing teams.  There are too many executives at the top.

job_title: Mental Health Therapist in Pasadena, CA
pros: Co-workers are nice, some training opportunities, if you are in a program with a good director who can shield you from upper mis-management, you may have a better experience.
cons: Poor leadership, does not seem to value employees (a lot of firings and little effort to improve morale), very high productivity demands and lower compensation than other organizations, strong emphasis on quantity over quality, company does not seem to really care about clients, unrealistic expectations, message to employees is that you're replaceable-no effort by management to improve conditions, poor quality of clinical supervision

review_title: Motivated me to learn more to advance professionally in the health care industry.
job_title: Data Entry in Pasadena, CA
pros: Good location, excellent co workers and management, training availability and great company to work for. They were constantly motivating employees by issuing awards and designating employee of the month highlighting the positive attributes of each individual employee. It was a very nurturing environment.
cons: Limited advancement opportunities for clerical staff and non competetive pay for entry level clerical staff. Tasks became redundant and non challenging after a while.

job_title: Head Start Family Service Associate in Atlanta, GA
pros: The experience was what I needed for my next level. Very hands on and filled with opportunities for learning. I liked working with them, co workers are also very friendly and supportive. Lots of on the job training
cons: I worked for the Head Start division of Pacific Clinics and it was their first year operating. Hence, lots of changes and not yet organized. Low pay for the experience and education required.

job_title: Peer Advocate in Los Angeles, CA
pros: PC offers lots of free trainings. I love the fact that they have PCTI. Their benefits are really good and the amount of holidays is adequate.
cons: One of the downsides is that management is very disorganized. There is very little room for moving up and the company lets go of good talent but promotes people who do not meet the requirements for a position.

review_title: Provide important service to the community
job_title: Mental Health Therapist in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Providing important service to the community.  PC takes their work seriously and is professional.  Excellent training opportunities.
cons: The work at any DMH contracted facility is difficult because we are constantly changing and bending to meet DMH with more paperwork, more billable hours, less financial support.

job_title: Mental Health Therapist in Santa Fe Springs, CA
pros: vacation time for therapists (20 days IN ADDITION TO sick time, etc.) , 7.5 hr workday (8-4 , 9-5, etc.), flexible time off for work-life balance
cons: Pay compared to DMH is lower, but similar to most contracted agencies.  Can be overwhelming if you're not a fast learner or really good with computers.

review_title: Great place to work for with people who really care about the clients and mental health field. Great benefits too.
job_title: Supervisor in Santa Fe Springs, CA
pros: Many opportunities for training, growth and development. Great benefits for paid time off and holidays. Training institute also a great perk for continued education. Depending on experience of management support and mentoring can vary for staff.
cons: Many different things are being implemented at the same time which leads to overwhelmed staff. Communication breakdown at times.

review_title: PC GREAT place to work for
job_title: Therapeutic Behavioral Specialist in Palm Springs, CA
pros:
Work environment is friendly and supportive of employees, the best employer I have worked for. Training is non-stop, benefits are GREAT and supervisors/directors are more than willing to assist you in helping your clients get the best services possible. This company is rated a ten.
One more thing, as of yesterday I do not work for this company due to health reasons.
cons: I can't think of any.

review_title: This company works you to death.  People come and go, and the sense of entitlement is extreme.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Arcadia, CA
pros: Many of the people are very nice. You can learn  a lot.
cons: There is too much work put onto one person. There needs to be more hands completing the word.

review_title: BAD QIC Supervisors; lack of knowledge passes the blame to staff!!!!!!
job_title: QIC in El Monte, CA
pros: very flexible, great holiday schedules, benefits are good..  will help with advancement if upper management likes you.....
cons: bad management passes the blame to lower staff,  West Valley Intensive division; program directors and team supervisor are a joke.    is not what you know but who you know here....

review_title: Their core values say one thing, reality is....they only care about billing.
job_title: Case Manager in Pasadena, CA
pros: Benefits are decent, pay is decent, co-workers are good people actually trying to help others, their funding to help consumers is above average.  The people that I worked with were great and we did great work with our consumers.  My immediate supervisor was great and our program director was a beautiful person.
cons:
Their core values state how much they care about consumers and will do anything to help them reach the highest quality of life possible.  But in reality, when evaluation time comes for case managers, billing is the only thing that matters.  How the clients that you are working with have progressed doesn't matter.   They will tell you that the only thing that matters is that you bill 5 hrs per day and nothing short of that is accepted.  They also don't care how you do it.  Coworkers took work home and averaged 2 hrs of work at home per day, others stayed late at work (both without pay).  Administration knew this and instead of fixing the problem they fired the person who brought the problem to light.  Workers are burning out at a higher rate than normal.   You are not encouraged to pad your hours but you are told to "do whatever it takes to meet your productivity".   
And lastly, no room for promoting unless you are willing to do a lot of "brown nosing", especially in their housing department.

review_title: Not one bit focused on client care
job_title: Anonymous Employee in El Monte, CA
pros: The flexibility and you are responsible for your work. Generally staff is welcoming and hard working.
cons: Management is horrible, unable to run a decent program, turn over rate is beyond comprehensible, you start and have an expectation of handling 20ish cases, no support, no clinical guidance, you are truly on your own, supervisor turn over is also bad. It's a really sad program. Thank goodness for employees who do their jobs, sucks foe newer hires, they are on their own.

job_title: Benefits/Leave Administrator in Arcadia, CA
pros: Community based mental health assistance.  Also does professional training.  For those who want to work at an organization that makes a difference in people's lives, this is a good fit.
cons: Non-profit so pay is lower than for profit organizations.  At the mercy of various funding sources that constantly change.  Employees spend too much time doing billing functions.

job_title: Case Manager in Pasadena, CA
pros: If you’re fortunate enough to have good co workers, then you’re set. 1/10 chance you’ll get a good boss, which will then sink the whole ship
cons: Paper pushing as if we’re in a sweat shop. The higher ups know absolutely nothing about a day in the life of working with clients, yet bark at us like slaves and keep adding on more work. They play the blame game and we’ve all seen so many good employees leave because of bad management.

review_title: Pacific Clinics Provides Excellent Mental Health Care
job_title: Receptionist in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Provides excellent therapy, psychiatric care, living skills training for the mentally ill after patient intake.
cons: Patient intake is not immediate; it takes a while before a patient is diagnosed; no immediate services for the mentally ill.

job_title: Corp Director of Benefits Establishment in Arcadia, CA
pros: Relatively Generous Benefits Package offered
cons: Very haphazard operations management. No consistency; job titles incongruent with salaries. For instance, executive assistances given Executive Offices, Corporate Directors were put wherever an empty space or cubicle might exist.

job_title: Clerk in Santa Fe Springs, Los Angeles, CA
pros: Staff becomes relatively close due to lack of management support.
cons: Complete unprofessional, uneducated staff. Management is the worst as they come.

job_title: TBS Coach in Moreno Valley, CA
pros: Benefits are great and I trully enjoy the vision as a whole!
cons: My managers and program director are sneaky, rude and Insensitive. I have been harassed and have been one of four employees who have resigned (in the past 3 months) due to stress and an unfair and uncomfortable work environment. I wish we could be like some other amazing PC sites. Ours unfortunately is horrible and I hate coming to work every day.

review_title: Mental health jobs should be about helping clients first and foremost
job_title: Mental Health Worker in San Gabriel, CA
pros: Directly helping people who need mental health services
cons: Raises are tied to productivity so there is a lot of stress about meeting numbers

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Arcadia, CA
pros:
Holiday Pay
You accrue Sick and Vacation time 
7.5 hour shift opposed to the norm 8 hrs
cons:
Little to no room for growth.
Management turnaround.

job_title: Peer Partner in Los Angeles, CA
pros: They are there to help people
cons: They don't take care of their staff..and make sure they are not over worked and underpaid..moral can get low at times and people leave..there's a high turnovers at Pacific Clinics

review_title: Enjoyed working with a down to earth open minded group of people
job_title: in Santa Fe Springs, CA
pros: Monday through Friday. Team oriented and goal minded organization. Great place to start if one is in need of experience!
cons: Non-Profit, so of course the pay is not  wonderful.

job_title: Clinician in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Great agency for many clients who won't get services any where else.
cons: No one cares for staff and there is no support for clinicians and case managers. They get treated as independent contractors but when it comes to saving supervisors backs, they get written up for no proper reasons.

job_title: Mental Health Therapist in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Awesome teamwork and excellent trainings, 20 days of vacation time, and you can pretty much make your own schedule as long as you meet your billing.
cons: Not high enough pay for licensed staff, and they require you to become LPS designated at some point.

job_title: in Arcadia, CA
pros: Great people and environment!  Executive Team is very respectful of you and you are treated as an equal.  Good benefits package.
cons: Pay is low compared to others in industry.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Corona, CA
pros:
Very supportive staff who work really hard to help the clients. 
Extremely inclusive and the clients or "members" play a big role in the program
cons:
The pay doesn't match the work that you will have to do for the "members"
Location
Billing and billing requirements per day

job_title: About to BE Laid Off in Riverside, CA
pros: A few good people. Some good professional experience.
cons: Do not value employees. Right sizing the company means getting rid of many dedicated employees without transferring them to other positions.

review_title: heavy case load with little support
job_title: Mental Health Worker II in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Co-workers, CEU training opportunities, benefits
cons: Case load and DMH billing requirements too much for such little pay. Little support, distant upper management, poor communications between programs/departments.

review_title: I am so proud to be a part of this agency!
job_title: Job Developer in Pasadena, CA
pros: Great benefits, great people to work with, this agency takes good care of their employees
cons: I do not have any cons aside from the drive I take to work

job_title: Clerk in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Good pay, great benefits,  good environment, hours, coworkers are friendly and helpful
cons: You will earn your salary, heavy workload but manageable if focused on getting it done, flexible scheduling and telecommuting isn't an option.

job_title: Manager in Santa Fe Springs, Los Angeles, CA
pros: Excellent benefits, generous vacation and sick time.  Positive environment, excellent management team.
cons: Pay is on the low end,  not enough room for advancement. High stress job.

review_title: Too much expectations and small recognition to therapists
job_title: Mental Health Therapist in Pasadena, CA
pros: Great training if staff can manage high expected productivity
cons: In Pacific Clinics all is about revenue.

review_title: I love my coworkers, staff and clients
job_title: Mental Health Therapist in Whittier, CA
pros: I've been working here for over a year and I love the company and what I do!  Decent pay and benefits, great staff.
cons: Billing is difficult and stressful at times.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Pasadena, CA
pros: Management is great, employees are awesome
cons: Pay is very low... like very low. High turn over rate.

job_title: Mental Health Worker in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Working with  adults .Empowering clients  to  change  lives .Life  skills

review_title: 13 years great experience   then job changed , they are only concerned about revenue
